funder.name: Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Understanding patterns of species diversity relies on accurate taxonomy which can only be achieved by long‐term natural history research and the use of complementary information to establish species boundaries among cryptic taxa. We used<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcoding to characterize the ant diversity of Iguazú National Park (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">INP</jats:styled-content>), a protected area of the Upper Paraná Atlantic Forest ecoregion, located at the southernmost extent of this forest. We assessed ant diversity using both cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content>) sequences and traditional morphological approaches, and compared the results of these two methods. We successfully obtained<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content>sequences for 312 specimens belonging to 124 species, providing a<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcode reference library for nearly 50% of the currently known ant fauna of<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">INP</jats:styled-content>. Our results support a clear barcode gap for all but two species, with a mean intraspecific divergence of 0.72%, and an average congeneric distance of 17.25%. Congruently, the library assembled here was useful for the discrimination of the ants of<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">INP</jats:styled-content>and allowed us to link unidentified males and queens to their worker castes. To detect overlooked diversity, we classified the<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcodes into Molecular Operational Taxonomic Units (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MOTU</jats:styled-content>s) using three different clustering algorithms, and compared their number and composition to that of reference species identified based on morphology. The<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MOTU</jats:styled-content>count was always higher than that of reference species regardless of the method, suggesting that the diversity of ants at<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">INP</jats:styled-content>could be between 6% and 10% higher than currently recognized. Lastly, our survey contributed with 78 new barcode clusters to the global<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcode reference library, and added 36 new records of ant species for the<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">INP</jats:styled-content>, being 23 of them new citations for Argentina.</jats:p>
title: Mind the gap! Integrating taxonomic approaches to assess ant diversity at the southern extreme of the Atlantic Forest
